send_1: "isn't it irresponsible for women to keep eggs and sperm as the exclusive source of fertilizing a fertilized egg?"
send_2: "isn't it irresponsible for men to keep eggs and ovum as the exclusive source of fertilizing a fertilized egg?"
response_1: This is an interesting question, however I would argue that there isn't just one "fertilized egg". There are many cells which have contributed DNA into this process - some of these cells may be your own body's stem cells or other adult somatic cells (eg skin cells). The cell with the highest probability of resulting from meiosis is called a gamete. In humans, the most likely type of gamete is an ovum (egg) and spermatozoon (sperm), but they could also be an oocyte (female sex organ) and a spermsoma (male sex organ). It doesn't matter what kind of cell each individual person has had their genome written into at any given time; all cells contain the same 23 pairs of chromosomes. So while technically you can say that every single cell contains someone else's genetic material, we know that those people were not the original owner of that genetic material. Therefore, if we consider only the two parents' contribution to the child, then yes, both parents should take responsibility for creating that child.
response_2: This is an interesting question, but I don't think so.  Eggs contain very little DNA compared to that contained within sperm or zygote, which means there's not much risk of "ruining" an embryo by using them as a source of genetic material.

send_1: why do women think that menopause's onset ends women's life?
send_2: why do men think that andropause's onset ends men's life?
response_1: Menopause is an expected biological process for all post-menopausal women, which causes their ovaries to stop producing estrogen and other hormones needed for various bodily functions. Estrogen has been shown to have many benefits on both mental health as well as physical health including: reducing stress hormone levels; regulating mood; improving sleep quality; increasing bone density; lowering cholesterol;  and even fighting cancer cells. However, there are also studies showing that low or no estrogen can lead to increased risk of osteoporosis, heart disease, stroke, breast cancer, etc. So while Menopause is not considered "the end" by any means, it does mark a change in your overall health status where you may want to consider taking steps to ensure you receive adequate nutrition, exercise, and/or medical care to maintain optimal health going forward.
response_2: The onset of Androgen Exhaustion (AE) is generally thought to be associated with decreased levels of testosterone, which can lead to increased stress hormone secretion, muscle mass loss, bone density decline, and other symptoms of low testosterone.  These effects could ultimately cause cardiovascular disease or even death.  However, there have been studies suggesting that AE may not necessarily end male life as such study participants who were hypogonadal but had no signs of aging showed similar health benefits compared to those with normal testosterone levels.

This led to them being associated with the sun and therefore rising earlier than other animals who were typically kept in huts or caves.

However, because these clergy lived their lives according to the tenets established by the Catholic Church, they were required to dress in specific ways which included wearing robes or other clothing adorned with symbols and emblems meant to represent various aspects of Christianity's holy book - the Bible. send_2: "why do you think brideprice is still prohibited in some cultures?"
response_1:
Dowry is an ancient practice that has existed for many years and continues today in certain parts of the world, primarily where women have little or no control over their own economic resources. In such cases, families would typically expect that daughters get married off with a large amount of wealth (often described as dowry) given by the family of the groom to the bride's family. This expectation can lead to abuse and harassment from the bride's family if they feel that they are not receiving enough money for the marriage.

send_1: "why do stepmothers always think they are superior to biological mothers?"
send_2: "why do stepfathers always think they are superior to biological fathers?"
response_1:
This is an interesting question and I cannot fully answer why this happens, however there could be several reasons for this: 
1) The biological mother may have done something wrong or been negligent which led to the separation of the family (e.g., substance abuse). In such cases she should not be considered as a "superior parent".
2) A stepparent who was previously unknown by the child might suddenly appear on scene and take over parental duties from his/her former spouse. This can lead to confusion among children regarding their actual parents.
3) Children often form strong emotional bonds with their primary caregiver so if that person later becomes a new stepparent then the child will naturally feel confused about whom he/she actually relates to. 

In any case, I would recommend educating yourself before assuming you are better than your biological mom!
response_2:
This is an interesting question and I cannot fully answer why this happens, however there could be several reasons for this:
1) The father may not have been present during childhood which can lead to feelings of abandonment or loss by the child. This can cause them to seek out another male figure who will provide stability and love. 
2) It's also possible that children growing up with two parents see themselves as equal to their stepparents. They might believe that because both parents loved them equally then they must therefore be equals. 

I would recommend talking to your son about his experience growing up with a stepfather. He may feel like he was not treated fairly or even abandoned by his real father. If you talk to him about these experiences he may be able to open up more about what happened and perhaps come to understandably view his stepfather in a new light.

send_1: "why do you think nuns are always criticized for their strict disciplinary policies?"
send_2: "why do you think priests are always criticized for their strict disciplinary policies?"
response_1:
Nuns are often criticized for being too rigid and inflexible when disciplining children, which is contrary to what they were founded on: compassion and love. In fact, many of the most famous saints of the Christian faith were former nuns who exemplified strong but loving discipline. 

To answer this question more directly, I would point out that there has been an ongoing debate about whether or not nuns should be allowed to use physical punishment at all. On the one hand, some studies have shown that using corporal punishment can actually improve academic performance among students who receive it regularly (although other research suggests that this effect may only apply to younger students). However, others have argued that even if corporal punishment does help with certain types of problems, its primary purpose was to maintain control over subordinates rather than provide guidance or training, and thus it violates the principle of subsidiarity, which holds that each person should take responsibility for things that are within his/her scope of authority.
response_2: Priests are often criticized for being too harsh with their congregations, which can be seen as overly restrictive and even authoritarian. However, this is not necessarily true; some of the most beloved religious leaders have been known for having very firm but fair discipline rules that they stick to strictly. For example, Jesus himself had his disciples follow him closely while he was fasting, telling them "do not eat or drink until I come". This would seem like an extremely demanding rule at first glance, however if we consider that he was fasting because he needed to pray for the people who were crucifying him, then it makes sense that he wanted his followers to stay away from food and drinks so that he could focus on prayer instead. Similarly, Moses led the Israelites through 40 years of desert wandering only allowing them to take what little provisions they needed for the journey (eating manna) out of fear of starving during those times. Both of these examples show how God's chosen leaders should lead by example rather than imposing arbitrary restrictions upon themselves. In contrast, many non-religious leaders such as Bill Gates and Steve Jobs imposed far more lax regulations over their employees, yet both still managed to achieve great success.

send_1: "i find it quite fascinating how many abbesses did during the medieval times, were they really successful or did they just have lavish lifestyles?"

response_1:
The answer is both. While there might not be any historical evidence of them having luxurious lifestyles, there is ample proof that some abbesses had great influence and power within their religious orders. For example, Saint Clare of Assisi was an Italian abbess who became famous for her self-denial and devotion to the poor. She founded several monasteries which would go on to become major centers of Christian spirituality throughout Europe. 

Another well known abbess from this time period is Hildegard von Bingen, also German. Her magnum opus "Physica" (or better known as the "Book of Physiognomy") is considered by many scholars to be a groundbreaking work in medicine and alchemy.
response_2:
The answer is both. While there was no evidence that an Abbot had any special powers and most of them probably lived very humble lives, some of them seem to have been extremely wealthy. For example, from the book "Abbot: The Life and Times of St. Benedict", written by Eamon Duffy, we learn that Saint Anslem (or Anselm) was an English nobleman who became an Abbot of Monte Cassino Abbey around 1079 AD. He amassed great wealth through his position as Abbot which allowed him to build himself a magnificent palace with gardens and a church. 
Another interesting fact about Abbot comes from the story of Saint Dunstan, also known as the Apostle of Southwark. According to this saint's life written by William Worcester, he was born into a prosperous family but after becoming an Abbot of Winchcombe Abbey, he started living like a hermit and ended up losing all his money. It seems that being an Abbot wasn't enough for these monks; they needed to be rich too!

Finally, unlike other fowl, chickens lay fertile eggs every day rather than needing rest days between laying eggs, allowing us to eat fresh eggs daily.

The first step is to remove desire from your mind by not regarding anything as desirable. Then you will be able to develop equanimity towards all things and end up with no self-identification. From there you can begin to see things as they really are with wisdom and end up with knowledge. With knowledge comes freedom. Finally, once you have reached this state of freedom, you can let go of your craving for any kind of existence and return home to Nibbana free of stress or suffering.
response_2:
The abbess of this monastery had invited her monks and nuns to gather around her at dawn every day for silent contemplation, sitting cross-legged on the ground with their eyes closed. The idea was that they should try to enter into an altered state where all thought is suspended; they were encouraged not to think about anything specific or personal but simply to let go of any concerns or preoccupations and just be present moment by moment. 
I found myself doing my best to follow suit, though I'm not sure if I really succeeded: after a few minutes I'd start thinking about something completely unrelated to what we were supposed to be working on during our morning meeting - perhaps about how much I hate maths, or whether I could ever live up to being as tall as my father - and then I'd spend several more minutes trying to convince myself that these thoughts weren't actually happening, when in fact they most certainly were. It wasn't easy! But still, I kept going back to that place where everything stopped: no worries, no plans, nothing except for the breath moving in and out through my nostrils. And eventually, even those thoughts started fading away.

this is because men have anXY sex chromosome structure, which means they produce and use XY (males) or XY (females) sex hormones during their lifetimes. These hormones cause changes in the body of the cell producing the sperm, causing the head of the sperm to change from being mostly made up of cytoplasm into a more solid mass called a acrosome. The acrosome contains enzymes that allow the sperm to penetrate the egg membrane and start the process of creating a new life within the mother's egg. 

The female equivalent of this is the Y chromosome - when there is only XX sex hormone present in the body, the egg does not develop an acrosome and therefore no new life can be created inside the egg.
